Two bags of bedding used for the wolf hybrid enclosures were stored on the floor and ground near the enclosures. One of
the bags was opened, but not stored within a container with a tightly fitted lid. Failure to appropriately store bedding can
compromise the longevity of its use, as well as increase exposure to contaminants, pests, or other hazards that can
infiltrate the husbandry items. All open supplies of food and bedding must be kept in leakproof containers with tightly fitted
lids. Only food and bedding that is currently being used may be kept in the animal areas. Supplies of food and bedding
must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath and around the supplies.
Correct by October 31, 2024.

The program of veterinary care on-hand for today’s inspection was not completed in full. Upon record review, the licensee
stated they had an updated program of veterinary care available but was unable to locate a copy. The written program of
veterinary care affirms both entities (facility and attending veterinarian) have a clear understanding of their respective
roles to provide appropriate care for the wolf hybrids housed on-site. The facility should ensure that the written program of
veterinary care is available for review during all USDA inspections, including all required documented arrangements
outlined in this subchapter.
Correct by November 15, 2024.

The dates of administration for parasite control medication given to the wolf hybrids on a routine basis were not recorded.
Per the licensee, each wolf hybrid receives a dewormer monthly, but none of the administered treatments have been
documented or maintained with the medical records.
Proper record keeping is necessary to ensure that the guidance of the attending veterinarian is being followed, and helps
the facility verify that medications were administered as outlined in the program of veterinary care. The facility must keep
and maintain the names of all vaccines and treatments and the dates of administration given to dogs at the facility.
Correct by November 12, 2024.

Upon medical record review, test results were not available or recorded for the fecal, heartworm, and tickborne disease
screenings completed by the attending veterinarian. Though all ten wolf hybrids were tested, the licensee did not have
any documentation to account for the results after these tests were finalized.
Failure to document test results prevents APHIS officials from confirming the required oversight and veterinary care has
been provided, as outlined by the AWA. Medical records must be maintained and include the dates and findings/results of
all screening, routine, or other required or recommended test or examination.
Correct by November 12, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
